## So how DO I name a variable? And a function? And (why not) a file?

Letâ€™s try to answer the first one for now.

Variables can be named almost anything in R. Well, mostly, alfa-numerics, plus dot(.) and underscore are allowed. Some exceptions apply:

``` r
.1myvariable
```

That would not work. More to the point, I would not recommend it ğŸ™‚

Other considerations, besides whatâ€™s permitted or not, might be:

-   Long variable names end up being heavy on the eye, particularly when you do things like (in R):

``` r

```

That happens a lot. Yes, it did happen to me (more than I care to admit).

-   You also might want to consider that others might want to read your code, and so variables like â€œxâ€, or â€œtdffwdâ€ might not be too good either.

-   Then you come across recommendations out there: camelCase, dot (.) separator, underscoresâ€¦ Each of which have pros and cons. Too much literature on the topic to be convinced â€“ one way or another, with good arguments for or against any of these.

-   Variable names might include object information: Is it a string, so I can end my variable name with \_s? a data frame, \_df? But then this goes against the idea of making variables â€œshortâ€, or, at least, â€œconciseâ€.

-   Moreover, you might want to choose one way to go for ALL the coding languages you use (or, well, as many as possible). So in Python (usually Python is â€œright thereâ€ when you talk about R), calling an objectâ€™s method uses the dot (.), which in turn might push you away from it for your day-to-day variable naming conventions.

At the end of the day, I chose the following:

-   I use **underscore (\_)**, to separate words in the variable names. This is subject to debate out there, but thatâ€™s just my choice ğŸ™‚

-   I use **all lower-case** for all variable names, and for functions. This is not a recommendation, you can come up with your own system of course. I can differentiate simply because if Iâ€™m calling a function, there will be a () after it (duh!)

-   I try to use real complete words, or â€œstemsâ€ where it makes sense, to keep it short.

-   I agree with the concept of **â€œnounsâ€ for variable names, and â€œverbsâ€ for functions**.

-   I have â€œshortcutsâ€: For example, I use â€œnâ€ for a number, usually a quantity/count.
